message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with psoriasis, and since the affected area is less than 3% of the total body surface area, the best initial therapy would be topical clobetasol and/or topical calcipotriol. Methotrexate and Cyclosporine are used for severe psoriasis, while oral prednisolone is not the first-line treatment for psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation is consistent with psoriasis, and the mild involvement (less than 3% of body surface area) warrants initial treatment with topical agents such as clobetasol and/or calcipotriol. Methotrexate and cyclosporine are reserved for moderate-to-severe psoriasis, while oral prednisolone is not a first-line treatment for psoriasis and can worsen the condition with long-term use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest psoriasis, which is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the skin. Topical clobetasol and/or topical calcipotriol are the best initial therapy for limited psoriasis. Methotrexate, cyclosporine and oral prednisolone are used for more severe cases of psoriasis. It is worth noting that while lisinopril can cause skin rash as a side effect, it is unlikely to be related to the patient’s psoriasis since the rash has been episodic since he was a teenager.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with psoriasis, which is a chronic condition with exacerbations and remissions. As the affected area is less than 3% of the total body surface area, topical treatment can be used as initial therapy. Topical clobetasol is a high-potency corticosteroid that can reduce inflammation and itching, while topical calcipotriol is a vitamin D analogue that can normalize skin cell growth. Methotrexate and cyclosporine are systemic immunosuppressants that carry more risks, while oral prednisolone is a systemic corticosteroid that should not be used long term due to side effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest plaque psoriasis, which is commonly treated with topical medications such as clobetasol and/or calcipotriol as initial therapy for patients with mild to moderate symptoms. Methotrexate is used for severe and resistant cases, while cyclosporine and oral prednisolone are reserved for life-threatening and severe forms of psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the rash and its location suggest psoriasis. The patient's medical history shows a recent diagnosis of hypertension and use of lisinopril which may cause drug-induced psoriasis. The best initial therapy for mild psoriasis is topical medication such as clobetasol and calcipotriol. Methotrexate, cyclosporine, and oral prednisolone are more aggressive treatment options and are usually reserved for moderate to severe cases of psoriasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has psoriasis, based on the location and description of the rash. Since it is only affecting less than 3% of the total body surface area, topical treatment with clobetasol and/or calcipotriol is the best initial therapy. Systemic treatment options like methotrexate, cyclosporine, and oral prednisolone are reserved for more severe cases or when topical treatments are not effective. The patient's hypertension and medication are not relevant to the treatment of psoriasis.

The best initial therapy for this patient is topical clobetasol and/or topical calcipotriol, which are commonly used to treat mild-to-moderate psoriasis. Methotrexate, Cyclosporine, and oral prednisolone are used for more severe cases or when topical treatments are not effective.
